#onthisday in 2019 I was fortunate to visit Lo-Ghyekar Gompa, an ancient Tibetan Buddhist monastery built in the 8th century. Located in Mustang, it is considered to be the oldest monastery in Nepal. 

Thank you to @great_panorama_treks who I highly recommend as your guide for visiting Nepal. They do treks (even for a not-so-outdoorsy city dweller like myself), expeditions, and climbs. Nepal is changing fast. Get in touch with them to plan an amazing trip and make unforgettable memories.

location.city_name: teamLab Planets TOKYO / チームラボプラネッツ

social_posts.post_text:
Amazing immersive digital art installation by @teamlab — roll up your pants and don't drop your phone 😂

"Drawing on the Water Surface Created by the Dance of Koi and People — Infinity"

"Koi swim on the surface of water that stretches out into infinity. People can walk into the water."

"The movement of the koi is influenced by the presence of people in the water and also other koi. When the fish collide with people they turn into flowers and scatter. Throughout a year, the flowers that bloom will change along with the seasons."

"The trajectory of the koi is determined by the presence of people and these trajectories trace lines on the surface of the water."

"The work is rendered in real time by a computer program. It is neither prerecorded or on a loop. The interaction between the viewer and the installation causes continuous change in the artwork. Previous visual states can never be replicated, and will never reoccur."

#visitjapanjp 
#tokyo 
#digitalartwork 
#immersiveart 
#teamlab 
#koifish

Santa everywhere!

#santa 
#christmasdecorations 
#christmastime🎄 
#festiveseason

In 1998, I was based in Jakarta, Indonesia. Without plans to be home in New York for the holidays, I assigned myself to cover Christmas in predominantly Roman Catholic Timor Leste, which was at the time a province of Indonesia known as East Timor

Context: It was 7 months after widespread student protests and riots in Jakarta led to dictator Suharto resigning after 32 years of rule. 

East Timor was annexed after an invasion by Suharto's forces in 1975. A bloody conflict ensued in the nearly quarter century that followed.

With the "strong man" gone but the Indonesian security forces still overseeing the half-island territory, a pro-independence movement was  brewing in East Timor. There was increasing international pressure on Indonesia to allow the East Timorese to decide their fate with a referendum vote.

Christmas 1998 in East Timor was without the throngs of media that descended in 1999 as incidents of violence between pro-Indonesia militias and pro-independence factions increased. The separatist Falantil army remained in secret camps in the hills at the ready, awaiting the return of their leader Xanana Gusmao who was still in prison in Jakarta.

Christmas Eve was a silent night. At Dili's main cathedral, children dressed up for choir and as angels for nativity scenes. Mass was led by Bishop Carlos Belo, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate.

Parishioners prayed and I could see the looks of concern, worried about the unknown of the coming months and what an independence struggle would bring upon them.

I quietly made images with my film Leica and 28mm lens. One frame in the set was taken with the first generation digital news camera, the 1.3 megapixel NC2000e. Can you tell which one?

#timorleste 
#leicacamera
#shotonfilm 
#photojournalism 
#easttimor
#christmas 
#christmasaroundtheworld

The kids have a Thai Buddhist father and Indonesian Muslim mother but growing up in the US we always enjoyed the festive get togethers and gift giving by our multi-faith extended family. 

Christmas has music (Bing Crosby, Nat King Cole, big band holiday concerts), magic and twinkle. My mom and dad gave that experience to my sister and I growing up in Staten Island. As a parent I wanted to give that to my kids too. 

When the kids were small there wouldn't be any presents under our plastic tree on Christmas Eve. 

We'd bake cookies (the easy Betty Crocker pre-mix kind), put a couple on a plate along with a glass of milk and a note for Santa. He would arrive after the kids went to sleep and appreciate the late evening snack as he made his rounds to the homes of good kids. 

The kids would wake up early Christmas morning. Dashing downstairs, they'd discover an empty glass of milk, cookie crumbs on the plate, and their handwritten note for Santa was gone. And there would be presents under the tree!

That is the magic. The awe and surprise on their faces Christmas morning is what it's all about for me🎅🏼🎄

Kids are a lot bigger now. They know who Santa is. Presents are under the tree before Christmas Eve. This year thankfully I got back my six foot plastic tree and for the obligatory photo they weren't towering giants over last year's 5 foot tree 😂

It's tough getting a full toothed smile from my serious artist son, but a yawn and a joke from his sister made the magic happen in time for the picture.

And if you're wondering what 19 minutes of opening presents looks like sped up 1000% watch the last frame.

Merry Christmas to all. Wishing you love, peace, good health and happiness.

#christmas 
#merrychristmas 
#christmasmood 
#brothersisterlove

I was too young to ever witness football great Pelé on the field but I was right next to him in 2009 when Brazil won their bid for the 2016 Summer Olympic Games at the International Olympic Committee meeting in Copenhagen, Denmark.

Pelé was overcome with emotion and warmly embraced the equally emotional Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva.

Pelé was legendary and inspired many. He passed away Thursday at age 82.

Thanks to @anthonyedgar888 for getting me there that memorable day.

#pele
#futbol
#worldcup
#soccer

In 2006, I accompanied U.S. first lady @laurawbush and daughter @barbara.p.bush for an audience with Pope Benedict XVI in his private library at the Vatican.

I remembered the strict dress code (dark suit and shoes) and decorum from my previous visit only two years earlier when U.S. President George W. Bush had an audience with Pope John Paul II in the same room. (I declined an opportunity to receive communion from Pope John Paul II that day, but that's a different story).

Photo ops are usually quick. We seldom have a chance to take in the room, especially when we are part of a traveling delegation. I was fortunate to be in the Pope's private library for a second time in two years, so I gave the room a quick scan.

I saw the artwork where the ceiling and walls met and wanted to get that in my frame. I dropped to my knees and slid along the floor as Pope Benedict greeted and walked with the first lady, making my photos down low with a wide-angle lens.

As I was quite effectively polishing the marble floor of the papal library with my knees there was a gentle tap on my shoulder. The photo op was over and we were ushered out of the room, past the Swiss Guards, and back to the motorcade to wait while the first lady finished her meeting.

The Vatican announced today that Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI passed away at age 95.

#popebenedictxvi
#pope 
#vatican

location.city_name: Shanti Stupa -World Peace Pagoda, Anadu, Pokhara

social_posts.post_text:
A couple of years ago I visited the Shanti Stupa at the World Peace Pagoda in Pokhara, Nepal.

Reaching the stupa is an easy hike up Anadu Hill and also offers beautiful views of Fewa Lake, Pokhara city, and the Himalayas on a clear day.

The pagoda has Buddha images from Sri Lanka, Japan, Thailand, and Nepal representing various stages in Buddha's life.

I couldn't help but chuckle after seeing the multitude of signs reminding visitors of the rules. 🤫

Thanks to @great_panorama_treks
for guiding us on our visit.

#visitnepal
#pokhara
#buddha 
#buddhist 
#rules 
#greatpanoramatreks
#xiaomi 
#xiaominote8pro

I was saddened to hear about the passing of Lisa Marie Presley at age 54. 

I last photographed her when she and her mom Priscilla gave U.S. President George W. Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi a tour of Graceland in Memphis, Tennessee, on June 30, 2006.

Koizumi is a huge Elvis fan. I was positioned with the traveling White House press behind a sofa in the "Jungle Room"  which had green shag carpet on the floor and ceiling.

The Japanese Prime Minister picked up a pair of Elvis's sunglasses on the coffee table and put them on, and then pretended to play air guitar. He later examined a wallet belonging to Elvis which was on a side table.

#lisamariepresley 
#graceland
#elvis 
#elvispresley

My soon to graduate from high school son wants to pursue visual arts and architecture.

As a dad I support his creativity and want to expose him to as much potential inspiration as possible. So I brought him to the art expo.

"This isn't curated," he told me. And he was right. That said, he got a taste of how art can also be commerce, where buyers, galleries, and artists come together in an ecosystem that hopefully sustains creativity in the future!

#lovemyson 
#makeart 
#artsg

Tonight was the first performance of a four-night engagement of a production of West Side Story — one of my favorite musicals whose 1961 film adaptation captivated me as a child. 

The music composed by Leonard Bernstein with lyrics by Stephen Sondheim made such an impression on me. I still get very emotional and always (always! Not joking) shed a tear during the lyric "Say it softly and it's almost like praying" in Maria, and the final two chords in the finale "Somewhere" — really powerful stuff for me.

I'm playing the Reed III book which has parts for piccolo, flute, Bb clarinet, oboe, English Horn, tenor sax, bari sax, and bass clarinet which I'm cheating a bit and covering (and transposing) those parts on three saxophones. (My clarinet chops are rusty and I need to get to the flute to be a true woodwind doubler.)

Thanks to @fabianlimsaxophonist for giving me the call for this gig. You didn't know that West Side Story means a lot to me!

Congratulations to the young performers and my fellow musicians (they are ALL PROS — it's a tough score so the big guns were called in, and we only had three days of rehearsal).

Looking forward to the rest of the week.

Thank you @doraemonexhibitsg @leyouki_sg for putting together a wonderful exhibition of Japanese manga artist Fujiko F. Fujio who created the Japanese manga Doraemon which I watched on TV (translated to Thai) during my childhood summers in Bangkok. 

Nobita and his neighborhood friends' adventures with Doraemon — the robot cat from the future with endless gadgets — was simply magic for my sister and I.

Part of the exhibit were also works by Japanese and Singapore artists paying homage to Doraemon and the influence that Fujio's tales of fantasy and friendship influenced their lives.

#doraemon 
#fujikoffujio 
#manga

I asked my teenage son (the up and coming artist) what he thought about Keith Haring's artwork being sold on microwave safe noodle bowls (with chopsticks), tumblers, and rugs in the mall.

"Dad, it's gross," he replied.

When I was a little younger than he is now, I read about Keith Haring in Interview magazine and made the trip from Staten Island (via train and ferry) to his Pop Shop on Lafayette Street in Manhattan. The merchandising of his art was in full swing even back then.

According to @keithharingfoundation Haring said, "The use of commercial projects has enabled me to reach millions of people whom I would not have reached by remaining an unknown artist. I assumed, after all, that the point of making art was to communicate and contribute to culture.”

Artists communicate in different ways. I'm looking forward to seeing how my son chooses to do it.

I did leave Pop Shop that day with a T-shirt.

PS: Love this song, by the way. Indeep!

#makeart
#keithharing 
#typo

In my early days of making pictures I may have been guilty of too often incorporating Buddhist monks in my street photography or "daily life" photo features.

Buddhist monks at the cash machine. Waiting in train stations and airports. Buddhist monks looking at mobile phones in a mall, or in a computer shop. Buddhist monks as tourists photographing themselves with cherry blossoms at the Tidal Basin in Washington DC. 

In many ways it's a photographic "crutch" — the saffron robes "pop" and the juxtaposition of something traditional with the modern everyday.

I hadn't seen Buddhist monks on the metro for years. As old habits die hard, I lifted my phone and captured the moment.

It's been a long time since the last time (pre-pandemic!) And there's no other place but Indonesia to have the authentic, gastronomic experience of dining at a Padang restaurant.

Some of my go-to Padang restaurant franchises include Sederhana, Pagi Sore, and Sari Ratu. But one of my favorites is @restorangaruda_sabang which presents you with plates of spicy rendang (marinated cubes of slow cooked beef) and flavorful ayam pop (marinated skinless chicken steamed and then fried) 24 hours a day.

I've been known to come directly here from the airport, or making this my last stop before heading to the airport.

You only pay for what you eat and aren't charged for plates you leave untouched.

An abundant supply of locally sourced fruit at the neighborhood supermarket: banana, pineapple, young coconut, dragonfruit, avocado, rambutan, and durian. (Ok, the durian came from further away in Thailand.)

When Louis Prima sang "Yes! We Have No Bananas" he would never have dreamt that it could all be found at @pepito.market on the other side of the world.

Life goes by fast. Stop and smell the melons!

I'm lucky that I sometimes get a second chance at capturing a fleeting moment. 

I was 20 meters away (by the dragon fruit) when I saw the curious movement of large yellow melon to face. I tend to gravitate towards endearing and humorous gestures so I quietly approached.

The man didn't seem to notice as I lifted my smartphone and snapped as he brought another melon to his nose and inhaled deeply. Seemingly satisfied with his choice, he walked away with the melon and I continued with my shopping.

I agree that photo would have been better were it durian.

#fruit 
#supermarket
#thebestthingsinlifearefree 
#stopandsmelltheroses
#dontsqueezethecharmin

A big congratulations to @michelleyeoh_official for the Best Actress Oscar for her role in "Everything Everywhere All at Once."

I wanted to share some images of when I first photographed her almost 26 years ago on May 15, 1997, in Bangkok with @piercebrosnanofficial.

It was a mid-production news conference for the 18th James Bond film "Tomorrow Never Dies" which was shooting in Bangkok (location doubling for Saigon in the film). 

The actors arrived via boat in the hot midday sun at the Shangri-La Hotel pier on the Chao Phraya River and were given welcome garlands of jasmine flowers.

Michelle Yeoh is the first Asian woman to win the Oscar for best actress.

"For all the little boys and girls who look like me watching tonight, this is a beacon of hope and possibilities," Yeoh said in her acceptance speech. "This is proof that dreams dream big and dreams do come true."

#michelleyeoh
#michelleyeoh_official
#oscars
#everythingeverywhereallatonce
#007
#shotonfilm

Got to see my son in uniform playing softball for the first time the other week. 

First time?😮

Yup.

For two seasons, he was committed. Getting up at 6 am on school days for practice. Saturday practices. There were home games at school during the pandemic, but there was always a reason I couldn't go watch:

"No parents allowed, dad." 🤔

When's the next game?

"There's no schedule, dad."🤨

Finally, I had a scrap of intel: 

"I have a game today at 430pm at X school — but they won't allow you in, dad."🙄

"They won't let me in? We'll see about that!" thought this photojournalist who has talked his way into plenty of places.😎

I showed up at the other school an hour early with one camera, one lens (because it's best to be subtle when access is uncertain), and a smile on my face. 

"I'm here for the softball game. My son is on the visiting team." 

And just like that, I got my visitor's pass 🫡

I positioned myself in the bleachers. The host team was warming up. My son's team arrived half an hour later, and they started warming up. 

I was the only visiting parent. He finally looked up at the top row and saw me there. 🤫 I first got a look of shock and surprise, and then a smile.

It was a spirited game. He caught a fly ball in center field and later rounded the bases and brought in three runs. His team won. This proud dad was finally there to capture the moment.

I found some pictures from YMCA tee ball 13 years earlier and put together some photo combos. 🥎📸

#prouddad 
#softball 
#fatherandson 
#fatherhood 
#canon100400ii

She's on Instagram, but I won't tag her in hopes she misses this post (she's gonna kill me for posting these). 

Thanks to my parents for having these photos framed in their living room, so I could quickly snap and share for "National Siblings Day," which is April 10.

She's only 15 months younger than me, and we were always a year apart in school. We were both accepted into the same medical program at university, where we took pre-med classes together (we were physics lab partners!) She finished and carries the family title of "Dr." in front of her name. I became a photojournalist instead.

I'm proud of you, sis! Thanks for always being there and supporting me. Thanks for always being not too far from dad and mom all these years as I worked for long stretches often on the other side of the world.

And thanks for being a great aunt to my kids. I'll include a snap of my second favorite siblings at the end of the set.

Love you, sis!

** UPDATE: Yup, she saw it, and I got 🙄 in DM 😅

#nationalsiblingsday
#brotherandsister
#sisterandbrother

A happy Eid al-Fitr to my Muslim friends around the world who are marking the end of the fasting month.

For six years I was based in Indonesia — the world's most populous Muslim country. Here are some images celebrating the end of Ramadan with crowds on trucks launching fireworks late into the evening followed by early morning prayers. 

To my Indonesian friends: "Mohon maaf lahir batin" (Please forgive me for all my wrongdoings in the past).

#eidmubarak
#eid
#hariraya 
#idulfitri

TWENTY YEARS AGO TODAY, I photographed the funeral of Air Force Staff Sgt. Scott D. Sather, from Clio, Michigan, at Arlington National Cemetery in Washington. 

Staff Sgt. Sather was the Air Force's first combat casualty in Iraq when he was killed on April 8, 2003. 
The start of the Iraq War was two decades ago last month.

Sather was a combat controller with the 24th Special Tactics Squadron at Pope Air Force Base, North Carolina. 

It was always the family's decision whether or not journalists were to be present at the funerals. Unfortunately, as the Iraq War continued, there were too many funerals of fallen soldiers to cover.

With strict guidance from Arlington National Cemetery, we were escorted onto the site and away from the site as a group. We maintained a distance with the utmost decorum and respect during the solemn ceremony. 

I dislike photographing grief. But it's important to document and amplify the cost of war. So it was a privilege for us to be there. 

Photos:

1. The Air Force Honor Guard members, from left to right: Staff Sgt. Albert Jackson, Staff Sgt. Ryan Moore and Senior Airman Dustin Williams; hold the star and stripes before the start of the funeral.

2. Members of The Air Force Honor Guard carry the casket.

3, 4. Three-year-old Danielle Harris, in blue dress, right, cousin of Air Force Staff Sgt. Scott D. Sather continued to cover her ears after the firing party fired three volleys of seven.

5. Air Force Lt. Gen Paul V. Hester, left, presents the flag to Melanie Sather, right, the widow of Air Force Staff Sgt. Scott D. Sather.

Smartphone technology allowed me to start the self-timer on the selfie camera with a wave of my hand. 

But smartphone technology has yet to come up with an AI filter to flatten my weekend-bedhead hair!

Dad was busy in the kitchen and I didn't want to bother him with snapping a picture of just me and mom. Besides, he would ask "why just you and mom?"

I was planning ahead. For this post. 😀

This photo was made two weeks ago when I stayed over my parents' place and got some much-needed catch-up time, complete with a set of fresh flannel pajamas and breakfast.

Happy Mother's Day to my amazing mom. Thank you for your kindness and support. And for all the details you never miss to make everyone feel loved and included. I love you. 

And to all the amazing mothers out there. Happy Mother's Day to all of you.

#mothersday 
#motherandson 
#bedhead

And just like that, we have a high school graduate 🎓 😳!

We are very proud of your talents and achievements, son.

And we can't wait to see where your creativity, curiosity, and kindness brings you next as you continue to explore, think, and grow independently. 

Always know that we are a video call or text message away.

Closing today's set of images with one that didn't feel so long ago: your first day of kindergarten 😄

We love you so much ❤️

I agree that it's a bit of a cliché homage to the 1980s-era MTV music videos (so many great saxophone solos), but what better place to take the Thailand-made polycarbonate @vibrato_saxophone 🎷 than the beach during sunset? I forgot my fedora🤠

THE GREEN SHIRT: Sometimes we can't bring ourselves to throw things away. And sometimes we forget that we even saved it. 

Today (at the storage unit) was one of those full-circle moments of rediscovery, remembering, and passing it on (rare!)

The Green Shirt was a staple of my early career "photo uniform" (I also had one in navy blue). A @dickies work shirt in cotton polyester blend that I asked my mom to modify: chop off the bottom and hem it into a jacket.

It worked well over a T-Shirt, keeping the hot sun and exhaust off my arms as I took motorcycle taxis to and from assignments. The material was tough and held its shape. Easily machine washed. The two breast pockets with buttons were handy in keeping exposed rolls of film, PCMCIA hard drives, and compact flash cards safe, ready to process, ingest, or messenger back to the bureau.

This particular green shirt has been everywhere:

Photo 2,3: At Aung San Suu Kyi's house in Rangoon, Burma, in 1996 - photo of me at gate by @richardvogel

Photo 4,5: In Phnom Malai, Cambodia in a Khmer Rouge camp in 1997

Photo 6: At a Bangkok club during my farewell party in 1997 before my transfer to Jakarta — photo by @stuartisettphotography

Photo 7,8: In Dili, East Timor during the start of the pro-independence movement in 1998, 1999

Photo 9: Catching a ride on an Indonesian C-130 from Denpasar to Dili, 1999

In the 2000s the jacket was retired. My "photo uniform" became Washington DC proper tan pants and wrinkle-free Brooks Brothers shirts.

Sometimes I save random, sentimental items only to throw them out decades later. 

Today I'm happy that my son — who'll never know all the places that shirt has been — thought it was cool enough to add to his wardrobe. 

Sorry that the left pocket button is missing!

#dickies
#handmedown
#fatherandson

If your pictures aren't good enough, you're not ... high enough?

Shouldering a plastic stool or two-step ladder was standard practice for unobstructed images in press work. 

We always appreciated a thoughtful site advance person positioning a 10-foot ladder (or scissor lift) at a campaign rally for that shot that gave viewers a sense of the size of the event. 

Or being able to peer out from a Marine Chinook helicopter over tornado damage.

And sometimes nature presents a perch that makes a pre-dawn trek up an Indonesian volcano for sunrise worth it. (I kept it light and simple and carried one body and a slim pancake lens for that photo op 😅)

Inexplicably, I do not yet own a drone.

Thanks to David Y. Lee, Jim Young, Pat Benic, and very generous others for the Charlie Up High Snaps 🙏 over the years 😀

12 YEARS AGO TODAY (before my Instagram account, before geotags and hashtags, before I got an iPhone — still had a Blackberry!): 

Sampling a deep-fried Twinkie at the Iowa State Fair in between chasing Republican presidential hopefuls campaigning ahead of the primary elections, Saturday, Aug. 13, 2011, in Des Moines.

I didn't try the deep-fried Oreos 😅

This year's Iowa State Fair takes place Aug 10-20, 2023. Go see the Butter Cow!

#iowastatefair

social_posts.post_text: Staircase, 10:10 PM

Moved first born to college last week to begin his studies in architecture and visual design. So proud that they gave you a scholarship award to pursue your talents.

Thanks for introducing me to your roommates from Turkey, Spain, and Russia.

Happy to facilitate an Ikea, Target, or Goodwill supply and housewares run again, anytime 😊

12 YEARS AGO TODAY — I was at Target on Route 1 in Alexandria, VA. 

First lady Michelle Obama — wearing a cap and sunglasses — walked into the store with her assistant. 

No one recognized her.

I decided to wait at the checkout line and made a few photos as she walked past me and out of the store, where she got into a waiting SUV with her Secret Service detail and drove away.

She was in the store for about 30 minutes.

I went back inside to pay for a few items I had in my cart. I went through the same checkout line as the first lady and asked the cashier if he saw anyone famous coming through his line just now.

"Oh yes, it was Michelle Obama," he smiled, but continued with his work.

I returned to my car and filed my words and pictures to the Washington bureau.

Thanks to Chuck Kennedy, who captured the photo of me and the first lady chatting about it a few months later as my son met President Obama at the holiday party for journalists at the White House.

Darling daughter is licensed to drive 😮🚗🚦🛑

#driversed 
#licensetodrive
New York, Bangkok, Jakarta, Washington DC, Singapore, and places everywhere and in between.
